shapes

Class Keyboard

  • java.lang.Object
    • java.awt.event.KeyAdapter
      • shapes.Keyboard
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.awt.event.KeyListener, java.util.EventListener

    public class Keyboard
extends java.awt.event.KeyAdapter
    Captures input from the keyboard. Keyboard, along with Mouse, is how you make your game interactive.

    For example, to make a shape move according to the arrow keys, you would write:

    shape.move(Keyboard.direction(), 10);

    • Constructor Detail

    • Method Detail

      • printKeyPresses

        public static void printKeyPresses(boolean printKeyPresses)
        Print keypresses to standard output. Most of the methods in this class use codes to represent keys, so this method can be used to determine which codes represent which keys.

        This class has constants equal to the codes for most common keys. For example, boolean upIsPressed = Keyboard.keyIsPressed(Keyboard.UP); can be used to determine whether the up arrow is pressed.

        Parameters:
        printKeyPresses - passing true prints all key presses.

      • keyIsPressed

        public static boolean keyIsPressed(int keyCode)
        Returns true if the given key is being pressed.
        Parameters:
        keyCode - integer representing the key whose presses to detect. (See printKeyPresses to find which strings represent which keys.)
        Returns:
        true if the key is being pressed, false otherwise.

      • keys

        public static int[] keys()
        Returns an array of integers representing all keys currently being pressed. Returns an empty array if no keys are being pressed. See printKeyPresses to find which codes represent which keys.
        Returns:
        an array of integers representing all keys currently being pressed.

      • key

        public static int key()
        Returns an integer code representing the most recently pressed key. Returns Keyboard.NO_KEY if no key is currently being pressed. See printKeyPresses to find which integer codes represent which keys.
        Returns:
        an integer code representing the most recently pressed key.

      • direction

        public static Direction direction()
        Returns the direction currently being pressed on the arrow keys. Returns null if no direction is being pressed (or if the directions being pressed cancel each other out, like left and right).
        Returns:
        a Direction object representing the direction being pressed on the arrow keys.

      • direction

        public static Direction direction(KeySet set)
        Returns the direction currently being pressed on the given key set. Returns null if no direction is being pressed (or if the directions being pressed cancel each other out, like left and right).
        Parameters:
        set - the set of keys to get directions from, either KeySet.ARROWS or KeySet.WASD.
        Returns:
        a Direction object representing the direction being pressed on the given key set.

      • keyPressed

        public void keyPressed(java.awt.event.KeyEvent keyPressedEvent)
        You can ignore this method. This method gets called whenever a key is pressed.
        Specified by:
        keyPressed in interface java.awt.event.KeyListener
        Overrides:
        keyPressed in class java.awt.event.KeyAdapter

      • keyReleased

        public void keyReleased(java.awt.event.KeyEvent keyReleasedEvent)
        You can ignore this method. This method gets called whenever a key is released.
        Specified by:
        keyReleased in interface java.awt.event.KeyListener
        Overrides:
        keyReleased in class java.awt.event.KeyAdapter
